DOC.HEAD: Grandson Has Ice-Skating Accident
Eds: SUBS grafs 2-3 pvs beginning `The White ...' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with number of stitches, president's stiff neck. Picks up 4th graf pvs `She started ...'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush gave a light-hearted account Thursday of a ``catastrophic ice-skating accident'' in which his 13-year-old grandson ``bit the dust.'' Young George P. Bush said later he had five stitches in his chin after the accident at a public skating rink about two blocks from the White House. The president also was ailing. ``I have a pain in the neck _ seriously,'' Bush told reporters during an afternoon news conference. The president clearly had trouble moving his head, and White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush got a stiff neck while lying on a couch Thursday morning reading an intelligence report. Fitzwater said a doctor gave Bush some medication, which he declined to identify. Bush described his grandson's mishap as he explained the absence of his wife, Barbara, at a ceremony commemorating the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah. ``She started to walk over here. Then there was this catastrophic ice-skating accident in which one of our grandchildren bit the dust. He's now getting a stitch put in his lip,'' the president said. ``Life goes on,'' Bush added. Jean Becker, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Bush, said the youth was getting five or six stitches in his chin, not his lip. He was treated by the White House physician, Dr. Burton Lee, she said. The youngster is the son of John and Columba Bush.
